Since various people here (not just peddlar) keep hijacking threads to "discuss" information, I've started a new thread on it. Kindly therefore sod off out of my "missing link" thread with such discussions and bring them here.
 
 Anyway to start things off, let's how a model that can be discussed. It's an evolving experiment that explores when information is "created", transmitted and received.
 
 1. Take a glass tube, partially fill with alchohol, remove the air from the remaining space and seal the tube. The level of the alchohol will change with temperature, but will be difficult (impossible?) to see as both it and the glass are transparent and colourless.
 2. Repeat experiment 1, but this time add a dye to the alchohol first. The level change with temperature can now be observed.
 3. Take a piece of card, mount the tube upon it and mark at various points beside the tube the symbols such as "$", "&", "@" and "#" so that the level of the alchohol lines up with these symbols as the temperature changes.
 4. Three times a day, look at the level and observe which symbol it "points" to.
 5. Three times a day, look at the level and observe which symbol it "points" to and note the time and write the two down on a piece of paper.
 6. Buy a "real" alchohol thermometer and three times a day, look at the level and observe which symbol it "points" to and note the time and write the two down on a piece of paper, along with the celcius value shown by the real thermometer.
 7. Sit down with the piece of paper and draw up a table with celcius along one axis, the symbols along the other and mark the table position where the two match. Use this to draw up a conversion scale. Write the celcius values next to each symbol on the experiment thermometer.
 
 So at what stage of the development of the experiment above is information "created". When is it transmitted and when is it received? This is mainly aimed at peddlar, but others are free to take part too.

 Huxley (1887-1975) said that, given enough time, monkeys typing randomly could eventually type out the complete works of Shakespeare. 
 
 Since then, others too, such as Stephen Hawking and Richard Dawkins, have made similar pronouncements about monkeys' random typing being able to produce one of Shakespeare's sonnets, or at least a sentence from one of his plays. 
 
 But when Plymouth University (UK) researchers installed a keyboard and computer screen in the monkey enclosure at Paignton Zoo, home to six Sulawesi crested macaques, it didn't result in a nicely typed set of the complete works of Shakespeare. Neither did they get a sonnet. Nor even a single word of Shakespeare. 
 
 No, when the researchers gave six monkeys one computer for a month, what they got was ... a mess.
 
 The first thing the lead male did was to find a stone and start bashing the computer with it. Subsequently, the younger ones came and pressed some of the keys. But most of the macaques' time was spent sitting or jumping on the computer, or using it as a toilet. (The computer was protected by a transparent plastic covering in such a way that the monkeys could nevertheless hit the keys with their fingers.) After one month, the monkeys had produced five pages of text, composed primarily of the letter 'S'. But there was not a single recognizable word in sight. The letter 'A' was the only vowel to be used, and it did not make an appearance until page 4.
 
 Despite the outcome being gobbledegook, the combined efforts of monkeys Elmo, Gum, Heather, Holly, Mistletoe and Rowan have been made available for sale in a limited edition book, bound in the style of a Shakespearean play, entitled Notes Towards the Complete Works of Shakespeare
 
 According to the science correspondent of Britain's Guardian newspaper, "assuming each monkey typed a steady 120 characters a minute (itself a preposterous assumption), mathematicians have calculated it would take 10 to the 813th power (10 followed by 813 zeros) monkeys about five years to knock out a decent version of Shakespeare's Sonnet 3"

 Boxer, Sarah, ed., "On the Rescue Gene and the Origin of Species," Discover, vol. 8 (August 1987) 
 
 "By definition, a new species arises when it splits off from a parent species. But a species is a species only if it doesn't interbreed with other species, including the one from which it arose. The critical question in species formation is how the barrier to reproduction is erected and maintained. As it turns out, the species barrier is a two-layered defense. There are pre-mating mechanisms--behavioral, ecological, and physical differences that make it difficult for two species to mate. If that line of defense fails, second-line, post-mating mechanisms ensure that the progeny of the barrier-crashers are either rendered sterile (like mules) or they die before reaching maturity." 
 
 "The rescue gene turned out to be strange indeed. While it weakened the general health of the flies that carried it, it gave life to their hybrid progeny. However, the gene didn't completely break through the species barrier; it couldn't render the males fertile. 'The flies live,' says Hutter, 'but they're sterile.' Which raises a troublesome question: If the parents that carry it don't benefit from it, and offspring that inherit it can't pass it on, how could the gene possibly have evolved?"

Ok, I might a little late in this, but,
 
 It has been asserted somewhere here that it takes an intelligent mind to records, store, and transmit information. Here are some examples in which that is not true.
 
 1) Trees
 
 The secondary phylum in most trees form rings around the center as the tree ages. The thickness of each ring is dependent on the rainfall each year. Therefore, not only do the rings store information on the age of the tree, they also store information as to the amount of rainfall.
 
 So, trees (no intelligent mind) record and store information in their rings.
 
 2) Bacterial Conjugation
 
 Most people know that bacteria reproduce via binary fission. However, many bacteria have a special trick that gives them genetic variability. It is called conjugation. Bacteria which possess the F plasmid have the ability to form a sex pilus with other bacteria. The bacteria then uses this sex pilus to send genetic code to the recieving bacteria. Many times, a sex pilus is formed to send a copy of the F plasmid across. Other times, an R plasmid (genetic code for antibacterial resistance) is sent.
 
 So, bacteria (no intelligent mind) send information (since many have the notion that DNA and genetic material is "information") to other bacteria on how to form sex pili and protect themselves from antibacterial agents.
 
 3) Bacteriophages
 
 Bacteriophages are viruses that attack bacteria. What's more, they are non-living. So, bacteriophages have no way of reproducing. So, in order to replicate, viruses attach themselves to bacteria and inject their DNA (information). This DNA get's incorporated into the bacteria's DNA, causing the bacteria to produce more bacteriophages.
 
 So, bacteriophages (no intelligent mind. in fact, inanimate) send information on how to produce more of themselves forcefully on to host bacteria.
 
 
 There you have it. Three example off the top of my head where transformation is sent by non-intelligent things, and one example where it is sent by an inanimate thing. What more do you want?

 It has been asserted somewhere here that it takes an intelligent mind to records, store, and transmit information. Here are some examples in which that is not true.
 
 1) Trees
 
 The secondary phylum in most trees form rings around the center as the tree ages. The thickness of each ring is dependent on the rainfall each year. Therefore, not only do the rings store information on the age of the tree, they also store information as to the amount of rainfall.
 
 So, trees (no intelligent mind) record and store information in their rings.

 Please read the definition of information. This is no different from water stains on a bridge support. It indicates how high the water was at one time. If you observe that it becomes your knowledge. If you transfer the knowledge to me in a code we both understand and agree on, English for instance, it would then become information about the high water mark. The high water mark is not in itself information.
 Information in a non material entity.
 
 

 2) Bacterial Conjugation
 
 Most people know that bacteria reproduce via binary fission. However, many bacteria have a special trick that gives them genetic variability. It is called conjugation. Bacteria which possess the F plasmid have the ability to form a sex pilus with other bacteria. The bacteria then uses this sex pilus to send genetic code to the recieving bacteria. Many times, a sex pilus is formed to send a copy of the F plasmid across. Other times, an R plasmid (genetic code for antibacterial resistance) is sent.
 
 So, bacteria (no intelligent mind) send information (since many have the notion that DNA and genetic material is "information") to other bacteria on how to form sex pili and protect themselves from antibacterial agents.
 
Bees transfer information and they do not have a mind in a human sense but they "know" how to tell the other bees where to find nectar. This is a transfer of a non material entity in a mutually understood code by two intelligent beings. The message also has a purpose therefore it is information.
 Dna is not information it is the media for the information transfer. Information is a non material entity , there are no exceptions.
 
3) Bacteriophages
 
 Bacteriophages are viruses that attack bacteria. What's more, they are non-living. So, bacteriophages have no way of reproducing. So, in order to replicate, viruses attach themselves to bacteria and inject their DNA (information). This DNA get's incorporated into the bacteria's DNA, causing the bacteria to produce more bacteriophages.
 
 So, bacteriophages (no intelligent mind. in fact, inanimate) send information on how to produce more of themselves forcefully on to host bacteria.
 
 
 There you have it. Three example off the top of my head where transformation is sent by non-intelligent things, and one example where it is sent by an inanimate thing. What more do you want?

 Finally, I personally have an issue with the statement that mutations are always a loss of information. As a matter of fact, there are several types of mutations:
 
 Point Mutations (changes in one base pair)
 
 A) Substitutions
 1) Silent Mutations - when the third nucleotide in a codon is changed, but there is no change in the protein transcribed.
 
 2) Missense Mutations - when a nucleotide is replaced by another, causing the codon to transcribe a different protein.
 
 3) Nonsense Mutation - when a nucleotide is replaced by another, coding for a stop in transcription.
 
 B) Insertions and Deletions
 1) Frameshift causing extensive missense - a nucleotide is deleted or inserted, causing excessive missense.
 
 2) Frameshift causing immediate nonsense - when a nucleotide is deleted or inserted, causing a stop codon.
 
 3) Insertion or deletion of three nucleotides - no extensive frameshift.
 
 
 So, there are many mutations where information is added. Claiming that mutations always decrease information is misguided.
